Delusional parasitosis is such an interesting and tragic condition. As a pharmacist with dermatology special interest, I’ve occasionally witnessed first hand patients presenting with the classical symptoms, one of which included a registered mental health nurse who acknowledged she had an underlying psychiatric issue but was unable to shake it. The condition is usually treated with antipsychotic medication and accompanying psychiatric care, usually in the community under a specialist - in the UK at least

What always fascinates me the most is how people with no connection, from completely different parts of the world present with the same symptoms. For example, it’s more informally known as “matchbox syndrome”, due to patients historically collecting fibres, hair and debris as “evidence” of the bugs crawling on or burrowing out of the skin. Matchboxes of course less common these days but replaced with similar small containers. I wish I knew more about the neuropsychiatry behind the condition

ex crack addict hear...crack and cocaine are completely different beasts. Crack is 5x as addictive as coke, lasts about a minute for a buzz vs the 30-45minute buzz for coke and is $20/rock. So that's 20 dollars a minute. A $100 gram of coke usually satisfies people for a whole night with a 3.5-gram 8 ball ($250) being the most usually for even hard addicts. The most I've spent on crack in a night was $1500 (1/4 oz or 7 grams) vs $250 for a 8-ball of coke. If you know the right people you can get a gram of crack for $100, most of the time you'll be paying $20 for a "piece" (.1 gram) with 90% of dealers. Crack is often portrayed as a poor man's drug, its the exact opposite. Yes its $20 for the smallest amount, with cocaine usually being sold in half grams for $50 bucks but considering that half gram of coke will keep you high for 45mins max and that 20 dollars on crack will keep you high for a minute or two, which one do you think is going to cost more?

I spent £60 on crack the first time i tried it and found out it was one of the most addictive drugs ever the morning after and never ever did it again. Ever.

Now here's why i need help. When i did crack i have a complete memory block. I remember parts of it like falling into the shower and took the doors off it, and banging my head against a sink; i needed her help to use the bathroom. The problem with crack cocaine and cocaine isn't so much that there are people who use it. There are harm reduction programs that can help people get off of their dependency.

The problem is that most people who use it consider themselves to be a part of a very large group of people who've used crack cocaine in their life and that group of people are cruel to the people who haven't used it. In fact, many of these people are such goofs that they attempt to turn people who haven't used it into their garbage bags. You know, by using it near someone. By buying or selling it in a transaction while someone sees it happening. As if by doing so, the other person becomes responsible for those habits of other people. Kind of like transference and criminal substitution. If most people who get burdened in that way never figure out that they're being used in that way, it seems as if it remains a protected secret for a very long time. The incentive for most users is to make other people responsible for their habit. To carry the weight of that secret so they can live pressure-free with regard to their habits in that way.


Another problem is that the people who import cocaine and heroin tend to be anti-Government or a part of a minimalist Government based ideology as most organized crime is. In fact, many people in on that supply chain use that power to control the people who are addicted to those substances in order to use them as their army in society. If you control the supply chain for an addictive substance, you can control the people who are dependent upon it. Crack dealers have been doing that to prostitutes for ages. Much the same, the people in on the supply chain use their power to control the users of the substance. There's a lot of power in that circle and a lot of corrupt people who facilitate the movement of cocaine throughout society. Having an army of people who are dependent upon that substance must be quite the power to have in society. I'd be willing to bet that if you got in the way of their goals, that you'd probably become a victim of that army, especially being an enemy of the people who control the supply chain.


Consider that harm reduction reduces that power, and is, therefore, a tool to protect Government itself, though as I stated, the Government doesn't use their supply chain over methadone to control substance abusers the same way that cocaine importers, couriers and dealers do. In fact, if any anti-Government groups were going to secretly overthrow the Government, I'd be willing to bet that they would fund it with the proceeds of narcotics distribution like cocaine and possibly heroin. They'd have the advantage of creating an army to protect them while they attempted such a feat, by controlling the supply chain of the people who depended upon such substances.


I've never used crack cocaine or cocaine in my life, but I've had people attempt to transfer the responsibility for their habit in that way to me and to the point that it nearly destroyed my life. When you're targeted by such an attempt, often it involves many people from the community. There's currently a secret underground economy that is protecting cocaine and crack cocaine, and attempting to hide it, and discredit anyone who exposes it, including by painting them as being a user of it and using the people dependent upon it to accomplish that goal. I mean if you supply it, you could likely pay those dependent upon it with the substance itself or deny it if they aren't doing enough to smite informants or people who expose their underground economy.

Most things of that nature would also work on a barter system for payment because it leaves no audit trail for investigators to track. I'd be willing to bet that organized stalking is likely run by organized crime many of whose foot soldiers are people who benefit from this supply chain of cocaine (which can be cut and refined into crack cocaine through many different stages from source to destination). Each time it is cut, to increase its yield which doubles its profits. So if it's cut four times, it is 16 times its original value. A million-dollar quantity of cocaine quickly becomes twenty million by the time it reaches the streets. That's the power to control a lot of people and to build quite an army.


One thing that's quite noticeable about it too is that most people who become dependent upon it tend to be more concerned with breaking religious law than they are about breaking civil law. I'd say there's a good indicator that some anti-Government religions are involved in its protection and likely benefit from the army of people dependent upon it. They probably mutually protect each other and would be against harm reduction because that undermines the power of the dealer over those dependent upon the substance and those who benefit from their power over the supply chain, who likely get rewarded for that.


Imagine if everyone dependent upon crack cocaine one day just stopped using it and only took methadone that they received from the Government. Can you imagine the shift in power that would happen as a result? A whole segment of the population who suddenly were in control of their own lives and getting what they needed to deal with their substance abuse issues without the people providing it controlling them or manipulating them by limiting their supply? What about all the women who ended up as prostitutes controlled by the dealers who were in charge of their supply. Could you imagine how many women that would save if they all stopped using crack cocaine and instead relied on methadone to help them get off of it?


I bet that would make a lot of cocaine distributors very angry, and help the honest members of Government and law enforcement immensely.

You bang your head pretty fukin' hard, you get concussion, you go to A&E (no fees for me NHS🇬🇧) and it seems bad straight off the bat, but you get checked over, you're fine and you're sent home.

Over the next few months the concussion reoccurs, your blood pressure is low, you're very forgetful and then you have a seizure.

You live a pretty normal life and have nothing to lose now you're going to die in a week.

On your last day or two, you start chatting to a guy in a coffee shop, it's your local coffee shop. You go every day, order the same coffee, then leave and go about your business.

Later into the conversation, turns out you explain your scenario and the guy empathises with you and asks "have you ever had drugs before."

Long story short, you've never had drugs before, he offers you to try every drug ever seeing it's your last day.

@Asapscience

I have no idea why so many people believe that opiates are worse than cocaine. I believe it's a social stigma effect, more than any other reason (cocaine seems to be the drug of the rich, while streets opiates, like heroin, are often associated with less glamourizable users such as homeless bums).
Opiates are actually NOT toxic and, despite the fact that their use leads to physical dependence, they present a vast number of beneficts, while most stimulants (like coke or speed) have little value beyond their (short) "feel good" rush. Opiates also create a slow release dopamine effect, wich is way more healthy than the fast up-down effect provided by stimulants. Don't get me wrong, it's important to have dopamine in the brain, in fact the longer you go without good levels of dopamine in the brain the more likely you are to develop degenerative problems (like parkinson), but while opiates contribute to prolonged high levels throughout the day, stimulants not only hold it there for some mere 5 or 10 minutes, but actually burn out the capacity of the brain to absorb dopamine in the long run (it eventually comes to a point where the brain CAN'T absorb dopamine, no matter the amount of stimulants you use).
Forget what society and media tells you. Opiates are NOT worse than stimulants. The type of people that uses each is not a good indicator of their (bad) effects and shouldn't be used to promote one while demonizing the other.

There is one pretty big mistake in this:
1:01 "Once in the brain crack and cocaine are effectively identical". Well the chemical compound that reaches the brain is, but there is a big, big difference in the actual neurological effects which make crack much worse. When cocaine is snorted, it slowly dissolves into the mucus covering the inside of the nose, and slowly seeps into the blood through the skin, meaning the brain will experience a slow gradual increase in the amount of drug it is experiencing during a 20-30 minutes period and then gradually decrease. That means the cocaine itself will protect the neurons from the oxidative stress the drug is causing. The brain will also have time to slowly adapt to the change. But when crack is inhaled, the brain is brought from zero cocaine to a full dose in 5 seconds. The end result is that crack is much, much more damaging to the brain, and its effects on one's mental health and abilities are also far greater.
I think it is a mistake to put crack and cocaine consumption in the same category, and also a bad thing for the purposes of prevention and education, as someone believing the two to be on the same risk level who already consumed cocaine in a festive context is more likely to try crack if it is proposed to them.
Also, and that's on the other hand more or less nitpicking, crack isn't smoked really, its inhaled as a vapor. Smoking would involve a chemical reaction resulting from the heat of an oxidative reaction (burning of a cigarette).

Interesting. I've done many drugs only once: LSD, DXM, MDMA, Heroin, and Cocaine. Every single experience was fascinating. I'm not interested in developing a "habit" but I'm certainly interested in consciousness in all it's forms. The one cocaine experience I had was incredible. For about 15 minutes, I was the happiest I'd ever been in my entire life.

What's interesting though...is that I wasn't happy for "no reason." It was more like I realized how utterly incredible and beautiful life ALWAYS is...it's like I REMEMBERED how perfect everything truly is...but had forgotten while sober. It's like I woke up to the reality of existence.

It was a truly beautiful experience...it was hugely therapeutic for me and, 5 years later, it's still stuck with me and had a positive effect. It's probably a good thing that cocaine is SO fucking expensive...because it would be very hard to not use it daily if it was cheap. I guess that's the allure of crack...same high, but less expensive.

It's pretty absurd that any drug is "demonized." It's not like certain molecules are somehow "immoral." What a ridiculous idea. Cocaine, like all drugs, offers a HUGELY positive experience. Does it have a downside? Of course. But, people don't use drugs because of the downside.

My hope is that, in the future, we engineer designer drugs that offer all the positives of the best drugs...without any of the negatives like overdose, addiction, and withdrawal. If we can create such drugs, it'll be interesting to see how prudish control freaks react. If a drug has ZERO downsides and still gets you high....then what could you possibly object to?

However, I think some people(control freaks) would still be against it. Some people seem to hate pleasure....especially other people feeling pleasure. Makes no sense to me.

Taking these drugs changes your body's chemical dependency in a real, physical way - that is what addiction is and why it's so hard for people to quit once they start, because your body is ALTERED by these drugs into requiring more and more dopamine levels via when your body produces more receptors to anticipate intake of unnaturally elevated levels of dopamine. But what happens when those receptors get nothing because you're not on crack? Disaster. Depression. You screw up your own body's dopamine/reward system when you take crack cocaine so that it no longer functions normally and you become more dependent upon the synthetic dopamine high from crack.

While I haven't smoked crack, I've snorted cocaine before. Wholly overrated and overpriced for what it gets you. I'm not of the ilk that all drugs are bad if used somewhat responsibly (though if you don't have a semblance of self-control, then control yourself at least a bit, and stay away), but I can't really see the positives of coke at all. I supposedly had colombian -- and even then you get high for about a half hour and the feeling is best compared to that of a nootropic (side effect free smart drug, they're amazing) stack mixed with coffee. Way overrated.

MDMA on the other hand has a genuinely meritable use in society I believe, and isn't physically addictive. Why anyone would purchase cocaine when MDMA exists for around the same if not cheaper price -- a substance which leaves you feeling genuinely empathic and enlightened even after the 6 hour "high" is beyond me. Even then, all drugs are to be used responsibly.

Actually, people with asma use inhalers due to the presence of adrenergic receptors B2 in the lungs. When the drug binds with this receptors it causes bronchodilation and facilitates air flow. It also avoids systemic effects from the use of other drugs, like adrenaline which is Alpha and Beta agonist, so it's use would increase heart rate and blood pressure and may not cause as much bronchodilation.
